There were hundreds of deer in packs all around the park. They were cute, they were in our faces, they bowed for treats. One was a bit cheeky and bit me in a tender place. To the Daibutsu. Had some Nara style sushi including mackerel, salmon, ayu (a river fish), and miso soup. We drank lots of water. I bought a children's yokai book. We watched some sparrows grab bug and bring them back to the hatchlings in their nest. To Lamp Bar for an egg cup drink & a gin drink. Met a nice British couple who were teaching near Hiroshima. Took a train back to our tiny — about the size of a walk in closet — hotel. There were loud kids in the next room.

To Haneda. Ate some Katsu curry. Took a plane and bus. Walked in the heat to the hotel. In a tiny tatami room. Cooled down. Took a train to Nara (*see Nara trip)

Slept in. Had snacks. Walked through a very loud pachinko hall. To Tsutenkaku, a very cute area. Had strawberry shaved ice on the big corner. Next to Okonomiyaki Chitose for excellent yaki, cold beer, lovely humans, and gift erasers. Walked down a Freemont Street exque area. There were many bars hosting karaoke with only a few people in them. They didn't look like they would have much English support, but they tried waving us in anyway. Played a gun game and pushing yen in an arcade. Then found pachinko/pinball like game with what looked like Superballs. Rested in the hotel. Watched Broad City. To Dotonbori. Hurumaru Yakiniku again for great meat and sake. Discovered ULFULS. Walked. Into the late night Donki and then a long walk home.

Stayed in late. To Freemont for Karaage. Then to Osaka Station. Visited the Snoopy store. Walkabout. Gay district. Detour. America Mura was meh. Ate Takoyaki. Back to Dotonbori. Ate more Takoyaki. To Sushi Zanmai.

Headed Osaka station. Ate a sandwich, spring rolls, and a sweet potato. Took a train to the instant ramen museum. Made our own custom instant ramen cups. Then took a train to Kyoto.

To our Ryokan where we met Azami and Keishi, our hosts. Liz took a nap. Melvin and I walked around the hotel area. We saw bird mating practices and found a nice quiche place. We brought a quiche back to Liz. Walked the town together and headed to Hida Takayama Kyoya for dinner where we had tofu, hot miso, grilled beef, and a good amount of sake. Explored the old town in the dark.

Ryokan breakfast. Bought some artisanal miso from the morning market. Rented bicycles and rode through the rain. Visited the market and the old town. Ate some incredible local beef on a stick while standing on the street. Liz bought a hydrangea woodblock print. We watched swallow hatchlings in the rafters of a shop. Sat down at a coffee shop for a bit and then went out for American-style sushi. Rode our bikes up the hill to the Folk Museum, but it had just closed. We rode down to the east side of town and explored the shrines there until it got dark. Found a majestic cemetery hidden on a mountain behind a shrine. To a well-populated area with narrow alleys and many small restaurants. Sat down at a grill-your-own-food type restaurant that had a not very hot grill. Played a rubber throwing star game and an air rifle game they had set up in this carnival/food stall lot. We were still hungry so we walked to McDonalds and had burgers. Back to bed.

Ryokan breakfast. Again to the morning market where we had an egg/marshmallow treat and some local milk. To the Hida Folk Museum. We were treated to some very beautiful views and spent a while exploring reconstructed historic Japanese homes. Yakisoba for lunch and then took the train back to Tokyo.

Entered Osaka. It was a big station. I got a beef sandwich from a station stall and ate it on the steps. It was incredible. Hung in Dotonbori mostly. To the B&B. Met Melvin. Back to Dotonbori. Had shochu and whisky in a stall on the corner. To Sushi Zanmai for a few pieces and then had awesome yakiniku & sake from Hurumaru. A girl was being flirty with Melvin.

Up and to bus. Running. Running late. Nearly missed it. Made it. To Takayama where we met Liz.

Dropped our bags at the hotel. To a coffee shop. I forgot to pay, but they gently reminded me. Walked the canal street. To a park where some event was underway. There was a woman singing on stage and many food stalls. We had melon soft serve, squid balls, and cheesy bread. Then we saw an incredible float parade (the cause for the park festival). Dozens of men were holding up large floats and literally running down the street with them. One float had a pyramid of probably 200 paper lanterns with candles inside. There was a man inside the pyramid whose job it was to literally punch out any lanterns that caught on fire as to not let the whole thing go up in flames. To the hotel. Very late night ramen in a very late night town. Many restaurants were open until 5am.

Up and transit to Kawachi Fuji Garden to see, among other things, the wisteria flower tunnel. Had pastries at the station. I hid sneaky puppy post-it notes all around for Liz to find. Many of the flowers were already dying off, but it was still beautiful and we had a nice time wandering the gardens. Conveyor belt sushi was oishii. Drank more coffee. Explored the west part of town. Hotel relax. The park was closed down. Went to Ichiran for very porky, very garlicky Tonkotsu ramen in isolation booths.

French pastry shop for breakfast. Wandered a bit more. Unctuous udon for lunch. Relax in a smaller park. Flew on an airplane.

Took an Uber pool with a funny driver who talked to himself a lot and a Dutch lighting artist. To the hotel. Ate ice cream sandwiches from the coffee shop next door. Took a bus to a food hall where we had some juices (sour plum & lime and a hibiscus) and a pad thai type crepe roll. Went downstairs to Hong Kong Soya Sauce Chicken Rice & Noodle (a.k.a. Hawker Chan) for chicken rice and char siew with fat noodles. Walked around Chinatown. Looked in street stalls. Visited a Hindu temple. Drank some Tiger. Even at night we were sweating. Went over to the Supertree Grove where there was a Star Wars music light show happening. Saw some kids doing scooter tricks. Walked for a while and ate some breaded chicken cutlet from a local stand. To bed.

To the mall part of town for some nice coffee with M.A.D. (macadamia, almond, date) Milk and a sous vide egg & lamb skillet. To Chinatown where they were having a dumpling festival. There was a wonderful woman on stage as M.C. who we watched for some time. We stumbled into the Buddha Tooth Temple, which was dark and exotic. Walked to the Maxwell food market where we had sugarcane juice, fried banana, gyoza, and carrot cake. Wandered south of Chinatown through a hip district. Back to the hotel to rest up a bit. To Long Beach Crab. The restaurant had dozens of large tanks with crabs, lobster, fish, and clams. We ate the black pepper crab, and aubergine pot with chicken floss, and lobster fried rice. It was all incredible and very buttery. To Sugarhall, a rum bar, for great music and nice drinks.

Same place as the day before for breakfast. To the Gardens by the Bay where we explored the Cloud Forest and the Flower Dome for most of the day. Headed to MTR in Little India for a nice vegetarian meal. Walked by the red light district and saw a line of men waiting to enter a brothel. Liz left that night. I checked into a hostel.

To Hawker Chan again for char siew. Then to Dapper coffee for Magic Gold Brew. I spent many hours in the National Museum where I also ate chicken wings and an ice cream sandwich. As the sun went down I explored Fort Canning Park. Then I had some fried rice for dinner at Jumbo. There I met some nice Japanese ladies who shared their food with me. Flew home.

Stopped in LAX (from Phoenix). Saw Ryan and flew first class to HK together. Had a good sleep and some nice food. Watched Curb Your Enthusiasm. Took the train into town. It was early, but our hotel let us into our room anyway. Showered and napped. To Hong Kong Station for Tim Ho Wan (Dim Sum): pork buns, rib meat, dumplings, beef balls. The tea tasted a bit like dirt. To The Peak. Walked. There was a long line for the tram up to the peak. It was very crowded and and surprisingly mall-like at the top. It was not serene; there were crowds of people all around who didn't mind nudging. After much waiting we got a pretty nice spot up front and watched the city turn dark as the sun set. It was quite beautiful. People were crowding all over Liz and one girl pushed her head over with her selfie stick. I yelled at her for it and she was very embarrassed. She apologized to me and Liz and seemed to feel bad afterward. Back into the city. Roast goose and sweet pork soup for dinner. To Honi Honi for some nice drinks.

Headed east to a food market. Saw mostly raw foods first, but then found the cooked food area. Split a yummy roast duck. Nice coffee shop for cold brew and a smoked milk affogato. Learned about fidget spinners. To the Ladies Market. Bought a spinner, then immediately had a Baader-Meinhof for them. Got foot massages. More Ladies Market and bought a wallet. To Kowloon Park. Saw an anime statue row. Ate pan-fried soup pork buns from a Michelin recommended place. Liz bit into one, but the hot juice squirted right up her nose and burned her bad. It hurt for a few days afterward. Nonetheless, the dumplings were fantastic and we still ate them, albeit more slowly. Wandered and back. McDonalds burgers and sleep.

I forgot to tell Liz Happy Birthday. Went out around 11 to get char siu bao, har gow, pringles, and milk tea. Brought them back to Liz for breakfast in bed. Left around 3. Grabbed a quick kebab and went to the Hong Kong History Museum. Learned how the British were the worst (like starting the opium epidemic to promote trade in the region) and saw towers of bao. Japan also was terrible for quite a while. Walked around the harbor on the Kowloon side and went back to the hotel to rest up a bit.

Up and to the airport.

Early flight to Auckland. I received a warning from the immigration person about how my travel lifestyle may look shady. They still let me in though. To the hotel. Dutch chips with mayo and satay. Walkabout. Stumbled upon the Auckland Arts Fest and listened to a nice Gypsy Jazz band. Work a bit. Walked to Ponsonby. Found Orphan's Kitchen and had incredible caramel butter bread, pan seared line caught fish, and a beer.

Slept in a bit. To Federal Delicatessen for tuna fish sandwich & coffee. Walked up and around wharf area. An older Asian (Chinese?) man was playing haunting, ethereal music on a type of rebab. An older folk duo couple were playing hymns. Worked a bit. Met Liz's colleagues for a drink and dinner by the wharf. To Housebar for a Penicillin and a Floral Fizz.

Work. Ramen. Blue Breeze for a very good Polynesian themed dinner and Tiki drinks.

Car rental. Drove in heavy rain. We were worried about being able to do Hobbiton. Stopped by a store and picked us some rain gear. Just before we arrived to Hobbiton the rain stopped. The weather was perfect for it and the lighting was incredible. Bought a sign for Richard's 60th birthday. Stopped for a few at a beach on the coast then to Whakatane. Met Juanita. Hung at her home for a bit. She then gave us a tour around the bay. Out for dinner where we had venison and tempeh.

Tea for breakfast. Juanita then took us surfing. We thought she was going to surf too, but she just stayed in the water to help us get started. It was very sweet and a lot of fun. I managed to stand briefly up a few times. Showered and then had breakfast and coffee in a local cafe. To some hot springs where we relaxed in the water for a bit. Drove back to Auckland and caught an airplane.
Locations: Sydney, Katoomba, Blackheath, Auckland, Matamata, Whakatane

Description:
To Basket Brothers for brisket and pork breakfast sandwiches plus great coffee. Saw a drag queen walking down the street, with an entourage of three guys, fanning herself. To the hotel. Went for Thai massages. Dinner at a posh Chinese restaurant where we had Pig (a cocktail), duck, mushrooms, and fried rice. Out for more cocktails at Bulletin Place.

Hotel breakfast with Liz. Headed to Katoomba where I met Henry at the station. Caught up over good coffee. Walked around downtown. Had drinks and wings at the palimpsest pub, which used to be a bank. A man tried to tell us that the center of the universe was out in the bush. The bartender gave us the look of 'Yeah, he does that'. Met Marion at the bra shop. Toured the antique mall. Picked up beers and headed to Blackheath. Explored the big garden, listened to records in their parlor, found a big spider. Grabbed a kebab & pizza w/Henry back in Katoomba and caught the train.

I headed to Sample for coffee. Liz showed up and surprised me. It was loud and windy so we headed to another place for coffee, tea, and pasta. Then to the hotel to relax. Headed to Fire Door for a wood cooked dinner of bread with smoked butter, prawns, pippies, potatoes, baby gem, and garfish. The staff was very lovely and also brought out a pork belly dish on the house for us. Everything was incredible.

A quick breakfast and then flew back to Tokyo.
Locations: Sydney, Katoomba, Blackheath, Auckland, Matamata, Whakatane

Description:
Mom picked me up. We had a nice vegan lunch in Palm Springs. Dove up to Yucca Valley and to their house. Met Jim, hung there a bit, and then headed to Pappy & Harriet's where we had a nice steak dinner. A folk band was playing. Suddenly the power went out in the restaurant and, as we would soon learn, in half of the valley. It was quite dark, but a few of the band members got together and did a makeshift acoustic show on the restaurant floor. The crowd was lively and it seemed as though the whole place was shouting the lyrics along when they performed I've Just Seen a Face.

Drove through Yucca and Joshua Tree on the way to Phoenix.

To IF cafe for snacks. Then to the Christmas markets. Snacked on potatoes and mulled wine. Down to the water. To Melvin's. Drinks in his lovely apartment with Johann. Dinner at his place. To Hemingway Bar for a first round of cocktails. Then to Anonymous for another.

Slept in. Melvin had coffee. 'Breakfast' at a bakery consisted of coffee, a ham & cheese croissant, an onion bagel with salmon spread, a blue cheese walnut quiche, and a sour cherry galette. Wandered the city. To a busy square. No Rousseau. To a rooftop bar for some drinks. To Louvre bar. Had McDonalds & spritzs at the house and played cards.

I picked up coffee and pastries for all from IF. To the castle. We bought some candles to place. Ate potatoes, fatty sausage, and a cheese thing. To see the Slav Epic, which was on display. We spent a couple of hours taking in twenty massive canvases. To a warehouse cafe that was very charming. Had risotto with demi sec. Wrapped up and headed home.

To Norwich. No vintage market. Thai: tea, chicken toast, pad see ew, Panang. Wandered. Market. Was handed a Socialist newspaper. To the B&B. Met Priscilla (a cat) & had a nap. To Strangers Coffee. To Elm Hill. Saw a Cathedral. The riverwalk was closed. Met the kind owner of fish & chip shop. Ate fried whitebait, shark bites, and a fried fish burger called the Big Mac(krel). Ate and drank at Birdcage bar. To the Norwich Arts Center for the concert. Paws was okay. Though sound was a little off at times Frightened Rabbit was very nice. I got annoyed at the couple in front of us and was not having a nice time. I finally moved and liked it better. To the B&B and slept.

The good: Priscilla spent the whole night with us, was super sweet, and didn't bother either of our allergies. The bad: she had fleas. We kindly informed her owner of this fact. To Strangers Coffee for good hip hop, nice coffee, salmon bagel, pistachio lemon cake, and good bad jokes. Rode the train to the broads. Wandered 'downtown'. It was quaint. Walked though some lovely neighborhoods on the water. Rented a private boat and rode the river to Horning and back. It was lovely. The sun set while there were hundreds of birds floating on the water. To the King's Head for beer and chicken strips and a steak & ale pie. Took the train and bus back to London.

Saw the Tree Cutter statue - a tiny wooden figure sawing a living branch in a large tree. Bocca for coffee. Singel 404 for sandwiches. Photo booth. Looked at many beautiful house plants in a shop called Wildernis. Nap and solo nap. Visited Salon Serpent for a quick hello to Angelique. Did the Anne Frank House. It was heart wrenching to say the least. Beer store for beer. Fries. Visited the Sex Museum and saw a lot of dick pics...statues. Crepes. No luck at Door 74.

Three beers and crisps for breakfast. Bocca: strawberry milkshake and coffee. To the art museum to see Colored Boy and other Jordan Wolfson works, KLM, 3D printed clay vases. Junkyard (hot) Dogs lunch. Bols House tour to see how their spirits are made. One experience was a phone booth like box you enter where you stare into a mirror, drink a shot of Genever, and are treated to a minute long psychedelic light, sound, and vibration (via a shaking floor plate) show. Smelled many spices. Finished off the tour with a cocktail. Bus home.

It was already late when we arrived to Briggeta and Uwe's place, but we stayed up very late drinking wine and chatting anyway.

Breakfast at house. Into Frankfurt. Bought some gummy bears. Went Kleinmarkthalle — a large food hall. We bought some sulfuric salt and digested oysters, wine, and sausage. To a cuckoo clock store. Walked to the main square and then back to the house. They made a local noodle soup, Frankfurt grüne saus, potatoes and prime rib. We drank lots of wine and other drinks. They gave us a tour and we spent some time in Uwe's train room. They also have their own sauna.

Breakfast at the house. To Mainz, where Uwa is from. Explored a church with blue windows. Walked a bit. To another church that smelled strongly of incense. Had coffee and baumkuchen. Visited a very interesting printing press museum. Old town for a good wander. To Hottum for wine, more wine, sausage, and schnitzel.

To Alexa's place. She treated us to lunch at Commander's Palace. To a blue ribbon table. We had cocktails, garlic bread, beignet, shrimp w/pepper jelly, more shrimp, turtle soup, sausage & rice stuffed pigeon, BBQ shrimp, and five desserts. After the meal Alexa gave us a tour of spice room and wine cellar. Had a nap. Put on some makeup to go out for the Halloween festivities. Alexa dressed as Beetlejuice. I put on some makeup and was sort of a drag joker. Liz was a cute bird. To a Tiki bar. Then to Cane & Table for bad cocktails. Down to Frenchman St. Listened to a live band and and met a few Tenenbaums at BBA. To Saint by cab. Met her boy friend. Had a gross drink.

Brunch at Red Dog Diner: prime rib benedict and shrimp omelet with crystal sauce. Drank a spicy bloody mary and coffee. Back to Lafayette Cemetery No. 1. Didn't see any cats this time. Nap. To Shaya for Israeli dinner. Ate lamb ragu hummus, pumpkin, brussel sprouts, peppers, halloumi, cabbage, and foie gras. Walked home.

Met Henry Krieger on the plane. He was a lovely human. He wrote the musical Dreamgirls. He gave me a book. To Sean's. Went out to a pizza restaurant and had orange wine, antipasti, pizza. Beer bar for sours. Fell asleep on the train.

Early bus. B&B. Bus ride through town. Meyers Bageri: cinnamon twist, cinnamon bun, poppy cheese fold, apple pastry. Coffee collective cappuccino. Vintage shopping; I found some sweet, barely worn 80's Adidas. Salad. Someone was in our room. Nap. Nap. Met Helen & boyfriend at BBQ place. Had a pear sour and sloe berry beer.

108
G&T & sparkling wine (like a sour beer)
Sourdough & whipped cream
Pumpkin
Bleak roe
Courgette
Raw lamb
Milk skin burrito
Lamb belly
Kombu ice cream
Nex to Lidkoeb for a daiquiri and guld maelk.

Ryan in. Pumped. 108 breakfast: Filter coffee and pastries: savory beef, sweet cinnamon, sour apple. Koji drink. Walked. Saw many beautiful boats. Tried for smorrebrod, but kept getting turned away. A girl fell, she maybe had a seizure, maybe not. Saw a nice hot dog. Ol & Brod: akvavit, smoked venison egg chive; veal brisket, chicken salad, tartare, other, mustard herring, pickled herring, spiced herring. B&B and nap. Ryan wore a bow tie. 108 again for an espresso.

NOMA
Warm greeting
Ordered champagne & nice wine
They brought out a tray of live seafood that they would be serving us.
New apple, black apple, oxalis leaves
Fresh sliced scallop, koji paste, roe sack, mussel stock
Plum w/kelp skin and plum skin inside. Flat bread, creme fraiche, ants. Nasturtium stuffed w/black currant, yogurt, and blueberry shell
Curled radish pie, beet juice, dried kelp crust, cucumber reduction & yeast extract fudge
Fermented bread
Dried tomatoes, fresh milk curd, black currant leaf oil, vinegar.
Sea urchin, cabbage, hazelnut, rosemary salt paste
Lobster, onion, lavender, butter
Butternut squash medallion, koji sauce
King crab, egg yolk poached in beef stock
Charred herbs, scallop paste
Whole roasted wild duck, plum sauce, cabbage, fennel flower, pickles
Mashed potato, plum compote, plum seed whipped cream, Akvavit plum sauce
Black currant oil ice cream, koji, oxalis leaves, lemon verbena
Moss cooked in chocolate, creme fraiche, kelp syrup
Cap mushroom, chocolate, liquorice root salt
Egg liqueur

Tour of the fermentation rooms, peaso, vinegars, top kitchen, testing lab, water tank, grill station.

Meyers Bageri for more pastries and coffee.

Waited for D&B to arrive. Met them. Got a car and went to hotel. Had a nice nap. Up and to Bar Luce for coffee, cocktails, bruschetta — roe & strawberry, shrimp & andalouse, salmon & artichoke cream, anchovy & creamy cheese — tiramisu, and pastries. Other than the pinball machines not working it was perfect. There were surreal black and white tile bathrooms. Into the city. Visited Piazza del Duomo. The weather was great and lots of people were out. Back to the hotel. Went for a late night McDonald's walk. Discovered our hotel was in a trans prostitute pickup area.

Nice beans for breakfast. To Bergamo. Found a nice street fair. There were many old Fiats. Saw some baby bunnies in a cage. Bought parmesan and a creamy cheese with pistachios and just munched on it throughout the day. Took the funicular to Città Alta. Circolino, an historic prison, for lunch: Bolognese. Pumpkin ravioli. The cathedral interior was the most ornate I've ever seen. Nice gelato. D&B bought shoes. Milan. Restaurant near hotel for very nice seafood pasta and pizza.

Tom & Jerry for breakfast. Construction workers were looking super Italian drinking espresso standing up at the bar. Dad drove to Como. Wandered the cute town a bit. Took a boat ride up the lake. Got off somewhere nice. Climbed many stairs. Had some coffee and wine. To a touristy restaurant in the main square for okay pasta. Running late to airport. Dad flew us there and we made it!

Landed. Picked up by Anne and Peter. To the house. Snacked on gache, croissants, earl grey. Walked the causeway during low tide. Saw a WWII trench, a Nazi bunker, and cannons. To the next beach. Ate ice cream and watched a beach motocross race. Next beach for a German bunker restaurant. They drove us around the island. Saw the Industrial North. Passed St Peter port. Walked to the end of a windy pier. Then home. Drank Gin. Took a Nap. Skyped the Millers. Anne made an incredible dinner of fish pie and a Victoria Sandwich.

More gache, croissants and tea for breakfast. Back to St Peters port. Walked around. Up some long stairs. Saw the old tower. To Lorna for lunch: daiquiri, asparagus, lamb, tart, curd, mallow. Relax at house for a bit then back.

Nomad cold brew and good filter. Weird B&B. Lie a bit. Patatas bravas at Turkish spot. By Gaudi. A nice place whose name I cannot recall for salted beans/shrimp and pig's feet stew w/grilled langoustines.

Hot night. Yogurt and cheetos. Nomad was closed. Found La Puntual. Eco flex veg for baba ganoush, chicken tacos, and iced coffee. Old city. Churches and shops. Bought a tarp wallet. Had some chocolate syrup. Went inside Sagrada Familia and were just confounded by it. Bus to Old city. Restaurant full so we did next door. Patatas, anchovies, croquette, oysters. Leche de Pantera for panther milk.

Felt sick. Lied in a park for a while. To a store for meat, tinned seafood, bread and cheese. Ate by the river. Hostel. Nap. Did the Guggenheim. I realized I don't like Frank Gehry's architecture. Some good art though. Warhol color wall. Louise Bourgeois cells. Picasso. To the City center. Had Wine and Coke (which is apparently a thing there), artichoke balls, green peppers, more.

Lie back in bed until 12:30. Bread and cheetos. Towards old town. Had the best patatas bravas at a place we stopped at to mainly get toothpicks. We unplugged a lamp to charge our phones. They may be thought we were weirdos. Old town. Crossed to San Fran. Three different coffee shops were closed. Gelato. Coffee, gildas, chess, wine. Park sardine, football boys. Hostel nap. Put some wine in a water bottle and ate razor clams on grass. Had an Aperol spritz, listened to a jazz trio, and played on a jungle gym in a type of outdoor space I cannot easily define. Someone snored all night in the hostel.

Burnt toast. No knives. People drank coffee before it was brewed. I was angry and we left. Cafe frappe and gross ham sandwiches at airport. Bus to Barcelona.

Flew a prop plane there. The busses were slow. Went to the canal where we had coffee, wine, and Pintxos with anchovies, zucchini, and peppers. To our B&B. Paula, our host was lovely. Napped and touched. Ate more pintxos: pepper stick and caramelized onion & cheese. Drank wine. To the surfing beach where we walked and played with sand. Explored the old city. To La Mejillonera for patatas bravas, calamares bravos, tigre (mussels w/tomato pepper sauce), bread, and beer. Wandered the beautiful town some more.

Liz worked. Then we had nice coffee, bread, yogurt, guacamole and an egg. To the beach. A young boy picked up a tanning woman's spare thong and walked around the beach showing it to people for at least five minutes. When she got up and realized what was going on she was not happy and chided the boys parents for allowing it. We were in hysterics. For lunch we had wine, an fried ball of artichoke, ham, & zucchini as well as foie gras pinchox with caramelized onion. Pintxos for dinner.

Left the B&B. Out for coffee, yogurt, and salmon. Then to Bilbao.

It was a beautiful airport. Picked up by Sara and drove with the windows down. The land was brown. To the apartment. Sara made a lunch of eggplant boats, spinach cannelloni, and salad. Siesta. Out. To the fountain. Saw a lovely post office. It had a large refugees welcome banner strung across it. To Gymage for foie gras mushroom risotto and spritzes. To a Vegas like plaza.

Instant coffee then to El Capricho park bunker. Park walk with ducks and frogs. To a gourmet shop for a foie gras burger. To Prado Museum to see Bosch (El Bosco), Rubens, Tintoretto, Goya. Reina Sofia, Picasso. It closed before we could finish. To a jambon shop with many hanging pig legs. Home for omelette, salad, lots of ham and sausage. Sweet bread.

Early up. Sara and Stephen took us to the airport.

Retro train designs with baby Brandenburgs. Neat and dirty city. Had a fruit plate and fish plate. Liz accidentally ate some margarine, thinking it was cheese. Photobooth #1. Photo gallery with great Berlin pics. Bough a photo of an abandoned pool. To the wall. There was an installation about survivors from the Syrian crisis. It was very well done and we both were moved to tears numerous times. Napped on the dirty ground. To the hostel. It was hostile. Met Emma, Phillip, and Alex for a meat heavy dinner. Emma had pasta fries. Beers at the music store/beer shop. Dark park wander. It felt like the beginning of the Warriors. Nearly played night put put. Learned about Weimar and the gay SA from Alex. Buck and Breck for Alaska: gin, Chartreuse, orange bitters and Caribbean Bar Fly: overproof rum, dark rum, Fernet, cherry brandy, Angostura.

Oily and crispy pancakes. Nicer staff. Big park. Swooping birds. Lie down in grass. Soviet memorial. Currywurst and sudden rain. Heavy rain. Really heavy rain. Done. Alex. Kebab & spicy halloumi sandwich. Beer and a walk.
Street drummers. Lovely apartment under construction. Colorful umbrellas over the narrow street. Coffee and tonic. Moroccan chicken.

The night before we left Stranger Things came out so we hardly slept.

Early flight. Picked up by Anne and Richard in Marseille and drove to the villa. It was incredible and was set on the side of the rugged and rustic hills of provence facing south across a plain of cypress and lavender. Had snacks and drinks on the terrace. To Venasque for a quick walk. Back to the villa for pate and salmon snacks. To Chez Serg for wine, sardines, warm salmon, lovely folks and good times.

Slept in. Pastries and coffee for breakfast. Read by the pool. To Le Barroux a quaint, rocky town with a church and a castle.

To St Remy where we toured the hospital Van Gogh stayed in while he painted starry night. Had a nice chicken dinner.

Pastries and coffee and goodbye to Anne & Richard. Went out with Nivens. To a town with an ancient Roman site and arena. Toured that for a while and walked around the town. Went in the beautiful church and had pizza for lunch. To another lovely town set upon the side of a steep hill. To Dentelles de Montmirail or the Admirable Lace Mountains. Napped by the pool. Liz and I painted watercolor postcards. Ate pasta and discusses, among other things, politics.

Straight to Holybelly for an incredible breakfast. Bought Suze. Met Liza at a bakery and snacked on salmon balls and eclairs. To Musee des Arts Forains or the Paris Carnival Museum: Skinny man, horse race game, three carousels, Venetian court, elephant hot air balloon, dark unicorn, velocipede carousel. It was surreal and lovely and super French. To Liza's. I made Suze spritz's and played piano. Snacked on treats. Dinner was burgers and steak tartare.

To a park market for oysters and white wine. Met Brad and Brian. Bought a buffalo horn comb and ate pistachio gelato. Listened to a very talented and emotive street harpist. To a Jewish deli. Many falafel shops. Did a walking tour and looked at expensive architecture. Liz was unwell so left the tour to lie down in a park. Liza and I continued. We also saw beehives in the park and busts of famous French women. Met back up with Liz. Saw a long fountain. Went into an empty church with a beautiful organ. There were marching priests. Then to a Roman arena. Drank beer. Lay down in the park. Liz was suffering from heat exhaustion and headed home. Liza and I went to Candelaria for lengua tacos and cocktails. I then got sick at a metro stop and threw up into a rubbish bin.

Gabe and Amy picked us up from the station. To bed.

Nice hotel breakfast. To the forest where we saw monkey trees, a log with thousands of coins suck in it, and a pretty bridge. Ate a 99 in the ancient stone circle. Saw many sheep and misty mountains. To a market town for a pub lunch. Gabe's hot potato took a long time. We wanted to take a boat ride to the next town, but it was too windy. Gabe and Amy bought cheese and Gabe ran up a hill. Went to the hotel where we played Boggle and Simpsons Cluedo (with much trickery) while drinking wine and spritzes. We were turned away from the Thai restaurant so we had pizza. Back to the room for hot chocolate with Fernet.

Breakfast and goodbye to Gabe and Amy. Got too close to some swans. Took a boat to Ambleside. Saw some cows up close and explored Roman ruins. We looked for otters then had naughty chips and BBQ fried chicken sandwich. Hiked up to the waterfall and then back down. Took some busses and trains home.

Anne picked us up. Men were singing on the train. There was a dead baby rabbit on the kitchen floor — a gift from the cat.

Chocolate croissants and coffee for breakfast. We drove through some yellowstone towns. One had a nice creek running through the middle. In one we ate jacket potato sandwich lunch. While visiting an abbey the held vial of fake Jesus blood we got soaked in a sudden burst of rain. We visited another town that was having a fair where people were getting wasted. They then held a donkey race. Donkeys collided and many people went down. The racers were covered in mud after, but nobody looked seriously injured. For dinner Anne made a fantastic chicken green curry from scratch. Drank some bubbly.

English breakfast and Antonia arrived. To the big abandoned house for an exploration. Picked up some raspberry curd. Explored a big church with games for kids. There was a very old crypt with lead coffins. Saw a mossy fountain and appreciated some modern ruins.

We were picked up by nice man and driven to our hotel in Fira. Ate some good falafel in town. There were many clubs with loud music. Went to a club called Absinthe. I ordered absinthe (on of the few there who do I'm sure) and Liz had a tropical drink. Picked up some pastries for the morning.

Ate the pastries and had coffee in the lobby while some asshole American abused the staff. We wrote a limerick about them I can't share here. To PK bar for a Bloody Mary and a Watermelon Bellini. Moved to a new hotel. Had a sleep. Got up and ate gyros at Lucky's. We both got pedis from a nice local woman. Visited a church on a hill. Ate gelato then had beer and snacks. Hotel pool hangout. Touch. Bed.

Rented an 150cc ATV. It had some trouble with hills and the trunk was zip-tied on, but it gave us the ability to tour the island in a whole new way. Had some bad pastries. To Parissa Beach. We had coffee and a cocktail. Had some chili and nice water. To the next beach. Ate at a restaurant with a great view that overcharged us for fish. Drove down some dirt roads and saw beautiful churches. To Red Beach. We hiked down to the very red beach at the bottom of a tall cliff. It looked very susceptible to a sudden landslide. Had some sugary drinks in the parking lot. Next to Akrotiri lighthouse at the end of the island. Hiked around there a bit. Did a meal at a nice restaurant where, when we drove by earlier, the woman owner gave us a big genuine wave and smile. It was an absolutely charming place where we had eggplant with garlic, baked cheese with peppers, moussaka, and homemade strawberry and chocolate ice cream bars for dessert. We bought some caper leaves and sun dried tomatoes in jars from their shop. I wish we could go back there over and over. We drove up to the highest point on the island and were treated to stunning views. Below us was a misty, fantasy world. Drove next to Pyrgos, our favorite town on the island. There were no roads here, just alleys. If M.C. Escher and Gaudi designed a town, this would be it. We saw many cats. It was basically true cat castle. Found twelve cats inside and out of one cute shop where we bought some bowls. We had baklava with ice cream. We caught the sunset as we were driving down the mountain. To Lucky's again for gyros.

Visited a magical grocery store near the hotel. It was dimly lit inside and smelled a bit stale. The meat & cheese cases looked like they were in a forest. Hardly any space was untouched. Nothing was in it's packaging. Every nook and cranny was fitted with an item. To Fira for coffee and gelato. The woman behind the counter praised us for our manners. Lucky's gyros again. I wanted to ride a donkey down to the port. Liz was not so fond of the idea, but acquiesced. It was frightening, exciting, and smelly. The port was nothing special so we took the cable car up. Napped. To Santo Winery where we hung for a few hours while doing a tasting of 18 smallish glasses of wine and more cheese than even we could eat. There was not much of a sunset due to the heavy haze, but we thoroughly enjoyed it all. A bunch of Americans flagged down a bus and got back to Fira.

ATV excursion day 2: the north half. Started with pastries, coffee, and a 300cc ATV. It was a much better machine. To a nice, but hot beach. Didn't stay long. Next beach. Ate at a quaint restaurant that took a very long time to serve us. Liz was a bit grumpy about this in addition to the fact that the food wasn't very good. We followed a tour group down to what we found out was a nude beach with beautiful views of cliffs.The group left and there were only a few folks around. I partook in the removing of clothes. Liz did not. The weather and water were great. I went swimming, but my mind was stuck on the though of sharks nipping off my favorite bits so I didn't stay out long. Drove to Ammoudi bay. There were octopodes hanging on a line. We ate tzatziki fries, grilled mussels in mustard sauce, and grilled squid. Back to Fira. More beer & Lucky's.

Rode a dizzying bus to Oia. We arrived to our freshly built, surreal-minimalist hotel. Went for a swim in the cool pool. Back to Ammoudi Bay again for a not-as-good-as-before meal. Walked up the cliff. Saw some sweet dogs and caught a crisp sunset from the steps. People clapped for it and it was pretty adorable. Had baklava and ice cream. Liz bought a ring. Picked up Olives and Cheetos from a shop and snacked on them while sitting on our balcony.

Liz woke up early to look for a kitten. No luck. Back to bed. Explored Oia a bit and had crispy pita, tzatziki, stewed beef & tomatoes, and roast lamb with onions & garlic for lunch. Back to Fira and then the airport.

People clapped when we landed in Athens. There were many potted plants and feral cats around the city which was nice. Slept in a hostel. Snacked on fresh roasted corn and nuts in the park. Sat under a dead lavender ramada. Passed the first Olympic stadium. The sun went down. Found a lovely church in the middle of a shopping district. Visited Baba Au Rum for rum negroni, chocolate cherry biscuit drink, Devil's Milk, and a Smoking Mexican. Late night pizza and falafel from a corner shop.

Liz woke up with a swollen eye and forehead. It went down throughout the day though. Freddo espresso and crepes from the 24hr shop. Walked to the Acropolis. Got hot and sweaty. To the airport to fly to Santorini.

Went to Sephora to claim Liz's free b-day gift. To Louis Vuitton to experience Akhob by James Turrell. Tool the lift to the top floor. The doors opened to a dark room and two beautiful women in all white waiting for us. It felt like the Milk Bar in Clockwork Orange. They offered us a San Pellegrino. We took our shoes off and proceeded to spend twenty minutes in space. The all white walls were washed with such even color that our eyes could not grasp the dimensions of what we were looking at. It was disorienting and incredible. To the Bellagio for a salmon crepe and a beet salad. To the Flamingo for some light gambling. The colors in that hotel are lovely. To some outlet shops. Then to Fremont. Saw a Navajo marionette. Drink & Drag was shut down. To Hash House for the big dish we love. More gambling, more losing. Video poker was fun. Drinks at Frankie's Tiki Room.

Flew first class to NY. Ate duck breast and watched The Day the Earth Stood Still. To Mother of Pearl, a super cute Tiki bar. Had Tide is High and Mexican Summer: watermelon sugar rim. Next to Please Don't Tell. Ate a hot dog with cream cheese and everything sprinkles while we waited. PDT: Pisco, vermouth, kumquat, cardamom; Celery, gin, vermouth, Cointreau; Chamomile, lemon, honey. Attaboy had too long of a wait so we took the train to the JFK to get for some sleep before our flight.

Quick stop in Phoenix for Cartel, In-N-Out, Target, Phoebe's grad, and CPK.

Then to Vegas.

Silje met us at the station and had made salmon, potato, and pickles. She test drove a car.

Eggs, toast, liver, and pickles for breakfast. To the cat sanctuary to help her clean and play with cats. Home and lunch. To the End of the World. Passed Munch's house. Ate burgers. Listened to AJJ.

Breakfast. Liz bought some nice bowls. Had lunch at the house. Walked in a forest named after an oil company. Went up hills that were Viking tombs. Liz and I made a roast chicken dinner.

Breakfast. Downtown exploration. Had a soft serve and watched flappers tap on the dock. Ate a fish cake sandwich and fish soup. Took the train to Oslo. Bought groceries and went to the boys house where we met two other Couchsurfers, Alex and Dan.

Had eggs, bread, and other interesting things. To a nude beach and a regular beach. Left the boys and headed to the folk museum where we saw, among other things, a very cool black church, storehouses, and a petting zoo. I think Liz maybe cried when she saw the bunnies.

Bus to hotel. There was a lot of snow. We slept a while. We got up and walked to the town. Picked up bread and tinned mackerel and liver from the grocery store. Walked to the water and took some nice photos. Snacked in room and went back to bed.

Had coffee, cereal, brown cheese, caviar from a tube, and pickles for breakfast. I was spacey. Got onto the boat, which had a sweet dog on board. Saw many pretty mountains as we began to head through the fjords. We learned about suicide birds, who apparently after losing their mate will commit suicide by diving down into the icy water. We tried to confirm this on the internet later and are not convinced it is true. Our boat began breaking up ice sheets as we entered less-frequented waters. Ate a lunch of salmon, whale, rice, salad, bread. We cruised by a massive glacier. It was the first glacier I had ever seen and I was in awe. There was too much ice out still for us to be able to go to Pyramiden, an abandoned Russian mining town, so we stayed on the boat and continued our tour. It was very cold in the boat and it was difficult to get comfortable. We passed a cabin on the land where, almost 100 years ago, a dozen men died because they were stuck there for a winter and got lead poisoning from cooking their food in the can instead of transferring them to pots. Back to land and to the hotel. We ate cheese puffs and cuddled in bed.

Same breakfast. I gave Liz a palimpsest Bel-Air birthday card. Explored the Museum of Svalbard and then hopped on a plane to Oslo and then Tønsberg.

Saw some interesting buildings upon entering the city. Met Espen by the Burger King. To Espresso House for creamy coffee and nice sandwiches. Walked through the city then home to Omar and Kayak. They were lovely humans. I talked with Omar about Javascript and Arduino. We had fun at the grocery store and then Liz and I made asparagus pesto spaghetti and cold chocolate bulges.

For breakfast Omar made arepas with black beans, butter, and cheese as well as coffee, bacon, and meatballs. Walked a bit and looked at the lovely homes. We saw a dog bar, an orange barn, and some very black homes. To Vigelandsparken to see many interesting statues. First on bridge: Baby. Women with aliens. Angry men. Up steps. Girl w/unicorn. Maze path. More steps. Monolitten, 17 meters of bodies shaped into a monolith. There were also 36 surrounding statues which included a mother being ridden by her children, a woman with oily breasts (from people putting their hands on them), and a child on pile of children. All of the statues were nude. To Uptown. Coffee from Espresso House. Saw some adorable architecture. The city hall was beautiful and looked like brown cheese. Ran to the ferry. Toured the Fjord. Saw the shipyard, summer cottages, the ski jump, Rodruss, and a fortress. Walked by the opera house. Students were dancing out front. To parliament. Nearby was the Stonecutters Freemason building. Saw a dirty clown. To Fuglen for excellent coffee. Spicy Thai. Then homemade pizza. Hugs and goodbyes.

Breakfast smoothies. Got a view of Oslo from the 2nd tallest building. Coffee and croissants. Train. Plane. Tromsø. Svalbard.

To the Music (Ska) Museum. Wide roads reminded us of the states. Museum cafe for full English breakfast, Jamaican sausage, and a Cappuccino. Some teenage boys came in and had breakfast with tea. Ben the Windy used the toilet. In the museum. Special event on the 2nd floor, we sat in for an interview with The Shapes, a punk band from Coventry in the 70's. Their stories were entertaining and they played a few songs, including Batman in the Launderette. Took photos with them and walked with a few of the band members to their car to buy a vinyl, which they signed. Great museum featuring lots of Two-tone stuff. Spoke with the parents of the lead singer from the Primitives. More used vinyl from the gift shop. Wandered the university and cathedral. Ate grapes, drank water, and and encountered some inconsiderate footballers outside of the museum. Did the Museum of Transportation. Coventry was the UK's Motor City. Very cool bicycles. They closed when we were halfway through. Ate some very Chinese food. Picked up beer and artichoke hearts from the store for our couchsurfing hosts. Met Marie & Joe. We had tea. Liz worked on their puzzle. We chatted about slugs, laundry, gender, and history. Had a cold, uncomfortable sleep on the floor.

Had a brief chat with hosts and then out. To Hampstead Cafe then the cathedral. The cathedral had been bombed in World War #2 and was rebuilt in a great way. Many diverse features w/intricate designs yet set in a humble, minimalist space. To the Grayson Perry exhibit in the Herbert Art Gallery next door. There were something like eight large tapestries there inspired by the Rake's Progress and many other works. There was also a great TV program playing where Grayson would explore people's homes. Finished off the Transport Museum. Had a beetroot chutney, beef rib ramen, and soft shell crab tempura. Train back to London.

Night bus-ferry-bus. Quiet station. Many soldiers. Early market. Met friends. Slept. Awoke. Had crepes. To Laeken Greenhouses. Pretty pictures, pretty flowers, silly humans, pretty humans. One room was straight out of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. Had tea and cakes in the cafe. To Peck 47 for great sandwiches. Took a film photobooth in a bar. It was malfunctioning and kept taking pictures of us. Wonderful! I bought two grapefruit and pretended they were my boobs. Melvin made us marzipan treats. It was cold at first, but the heater warmed up. Outside, above the cold city. I could hear birds having conversation. Sunset over the city. Liz was wearing a blanket that made her very cat like. We all did drawings. Melvin made a sweet blue milk. Ate crepes. Listened to music until the laptop died. Lights off. Turned on a star lamp. We made hand monsters in the shadows. Slumber party for a while until we finally went to our room.

Breakfast. Boca Moca. Same street market. Pin Pon for fish & chips and a lot of steak tartare. Plants. Vintage goods. Coffee. Rain. Spaghetti carbonara with egg yolk on top from Alexia. Took a family photo. Had a rooftop farewell and a revisit from my bird friend.

Confirmed secret phone booth entrance for the truly hidden speakeasy we would later visit. To Bold St Coffee for creamy portobello and garlic on toast and coffee. To Ex-Directory (the hidden bar) for a sherbert & tonic, a chili beet bloody mary, an Aristocracy Flip, and a Darjeeling Limited. The staff were lovely and we were the first ones in the bar. Did some shopping. To a Record fair and found an Undertones vinyl. Sat on church steps. It was cold. Many women in short dresses and very high heels. To Mowgli for treacle chips, house lamb curry, chickpeas in black tea sauce, mother butter chicken, and fry bread. No absinthe. Bus to B&B. We had a quiet host (who maybe was on drugs) and silly kitty.

The next morning she was a more sociable host. To the Walkes Museum for nice contemporary art. Bold St again for coffee and mushrooms. To the docks. Did the Tate Liverpool Museum. Greek statue and a pile of clothes. Bold St again! Maray for dinner: broccoli w/cheese, falafel, burrata w/honey and grilled peach, fried chicken thighs. Phew.

Caught a free bus in the rain to the Science and Industry Museum. Had hummus from the backpack. Art, recycling, large train engines, bisected engine, pump room pumps, cotton combing and spinning. Had a big plate of chips, drank some beers, and listened to And She Was. Took a color photo booth in a cute shop. To North Quarter to wander a bit. To Keko Moku for toasted coconut Mai Tai and Porn Oil. To Almost Famous for grilled cheese and a great burger. Found the renaissance picture spot and recreated it. Met David, our Couchsurfing host, at the petrol station. His house was surreal and dream like. There were keys all over the floor, there was color all over the ceiling, and there were panoramas taped up on the walls. We had a beer on the floor. He took us to the old pub with a chair nailed up on the wall that he told us Roger Daltrey sat in. A guy messed up a cover of a Matchbox 20 song. To a metal pub. A nu, eyeliner goth punk band was playing and an older hair metal guru was thoroughly enjoying it. It was a good culture smash. We slept on the top bunk.

Up and into the city. To Idle Hands for pungent cold brew and mascarpone tasting paper drip. To Rudy's Pizza for Campari soda, smoked mozzarella, broccoli, & kalamata pizza, and a tomato mushroom pizza. They were fantastic. Caught some ethereal African harp, drum, and dance in the city square. The weather was perfect. Someone was feeding dozens of pigeons. To the Manchester Museum. Saw lovely boxed herbs and a pineapple vase. We controlled a robot in another room and could see send communicate with people in that room. In another room, two sentient wheelchairs seemed to be having relationship difficulties and would print messages to visitors on receipt paper. Through the gay district. A woman on the street who had blood on her forehead asked us for money. We gave her some. Two stylish women — one as Marlon Brando. The other as Mary Murphy — had a touching departure at the train station.

Met Slobodan. Walked to the old city. Ate sushi and saw many cats.

Easter Sunday. No bakeries were open. Went to Pinkey's Bar for coffee. Liz had trouble taking off her pants because her shoes were still on. Ate squid ink risotto in a sunny square. Had some Nutella and caramel gelato. Fed cheese to some cats. Took a bus to the other side of town. Walked the water and sat on a rock watching the waves crash. Wandered town. Drank coffee in a posh hotel. Went to Pinkey's again for beers this time. Back in town for dinner. Found a nice place where we had two types of homemade gnocchi: 1) Croatian 'Dirty Gnocchi' w/beef sauce and cinnamon 2) with pesto, olives, shrimp, and tuna. Both were incredible and probably the best gnocchi we've ever tasted.
Locations: Verona, Venice, Ljubljana, Zagreb, Sibenik, Park Krka, Split Mostar, Dubrovnik

Description: Turkish coffee shops. Many men trying to get you to park in their parking lot. Crumbling buildings. Mosques. Christian churches. Small, dark shops filled with trinkets. One beautiful bridge. A man looked ready to jump, but was waiting for someone to give him money. No kissing in the Mosque. Had a lovely tuna pate. A jerk was being mean to his dog and it made us very angry. Down the highway. It was dark. We had to get to a parallel highway about 5 miles to the west of us, but when we followed the turn off we were on a scary, bumpy dirt road. We backed up and tried the next turn off. It was a similar bumpy dirt road. We didn't have a choice at this point. We didn't talk much for the 10 or so minutes it took to cross the valley. I certainly was not imagining getting killed by a gang of desert bandits. Nope. Definitely wasn't thinking that at all. We are big babies and we made it through fine and to Dubrovnik.
Locations: Verona, Venice, Ljubljana, Zagreb, Sibenik, Park Krka, Split Mostar, Dubrovnik

Description:
As we were trying to get down the tiny streets to our B&B we got caught, with about six other cars, in parking jam in a cul-de-sac. We were pretty much in the middle of the madness. I am okay at driving manual, but the skill needed to get out of this was beyond my ability. Fortunately a kind man, who turned out to be a local college professor and who is a whiz in a stick, hopped in our car and squeezed it in a tight spot that allowed some others to get out. To our adorable B&B where we met Tatiana. She greeted us with homemade Orahovac (walnut liqueur) and snacks. Walked down the water to Fife. We ate fried squid and grilled whole sea bass the proceeded to explore the old city. At night I read some Steinbeck.It felt like we were in a different time.

Had pastries on the slab walk. Saw bunnies, chicks, ducklings, and a box of snails for sale at the market. We had to pass through six different checkpoints to get into Bosnia.
Locations: Verona, Venice, Ljubljana, Zagreb, Sibenik, Park Krka, Split Mostar, Dubrovnik

Description:
To a nice B&B. Walked down small streets. Hung at a smoky bar and listened to the Spin Doctors. Ate some great pizza. Saw a cat and dog fight. The dog ran away.

Nice touch. I accidentally made a cup of foam with no coffee in it. To Park Krka where we walked around many waterfalls. There was a mountain called BJ Mountain. To Split.
Locations: Verona, Venice, Ljubljana, Zagreb, Sibenik, Park Krka, Split Mostar, Dubrovnik

Description:
To Ozujsko pub for cheap beer, burgers, and excellent beer sausages over fries. Walked up the mountain to the Museum of Broken Relationships, a museum featuring personal objects from lost partners and lovers. Read great stories about an axe, a melted medal, and an empty bottle of conditioner. Couch surfed with Robert, Maja, and Ferdo (their pet chinchilla). Drank beer and ate Milka with hazelnuts. Wiped the poop pellets off of the couch and then slept on it.

Ate cheesy pastries and out to a bustling city morning. Headed to the Museum of Illusion for many illusions. Liz found and completed a Tower of Hanoi; a puzzle that involved moving a stack concentric disks from one post to another. Picked up a car from the airport and drove to Plitvice Park. Walked along the boardwalk over the water. Saw some nice waterfalls and a cute duck couple. Rode a boat across the lake and then headed to Sibenik.
Locations: Verona, Venice, Ljubljana, Zagreb, Sibenik, Park Krka, Split Mostar, Dubrovnik

Description:
Lots of graffiti. Grey sky. Grey buildings sprayed with color. Makes me think this is what Berlin was like in the 90's. To the hostel. Explored the lovely city center. Drank spritzes on the river. Read some late night Steinbeck.

Slept in a basement. The bus was late to Zagreb. Apparently I took a guy's seat, but it wasn't marked and I held my ground.
Locations: Verona, Venice, Ljubljana, Zagreb, Sibenik, Park Krka, Split Mostar, Dubrovnik

Description:
It was a bustling morning. We saw weathered buildings, worn paint, and fresh tourists. We listened to an accordionist on the street who wore a Tin Man funnel hat, a kick drum on his back, and hi-hat somewhere else. There was a Psalm Sunday march down the street. The priests were singing a beautiful song. Overall I feel like Catholicism in Europe is a lot more interesting and aesthetically pleasing than in America. We paid an exorbitant price for our coffee in a cute square. To our hotel. Tatiana was lovely. There were swan towels on the bed. Liz bought a Venetian leaf mask for Richard. To the famous square. Saw some gondola. Walked to Harry's Bar for coffee and a bellini. Strolled the grand canal. Had a meat and cheese dinner. Touched

Breakfast was delivered by Tatiana. Made a spritz in the room. Took a boat to Cimitero, the cemetery island. There were flowers everywhere, we took some photos, and it did not feel particularly haunted. Next to Murano. Seemingly every other shop sold glass. It was very beautiful and we bought plates for Anne and Dad & Barb. Snacked on bread, snacks and coffee in the square. Sped along. Wandered the island taking great photos and having lovely conversation with my partner. A woman hung her laundry in a beautiful rainbow pattern. We were taking photos of it when she popped her head out and smiled at us. We did our best to communicate our appreciate for her temporary decoration. Boat to Burano where the buildings were painted in lovely colors. Watched the sun go down. Ate some cheap pizza. Saw more cats. To Torcello, where we hear a lovely rendition of La Vie en Rose on accordion. Back to Venice. Nearly stole someone's bread at the grocery store on accident. Strolled the town at night and rode the canal boat.

Breakfast delivery again. Took the train to Triste. Took the tram up the mountain and got on a graffitied train to Ljubljana.
Locations: Verona, Venice, Ljubljana, Zagreb, Sibenik, Park Krka, Split Mostar, Dubrovnik

Description:
This town looked like a painting. We arrived in the Colosseum square during golden hour. There were fresh flowers all around. We ate cheese in a cone. We walked along Colosseum. Sat down in a cafe in another square and enjoyed spritzes, a fine cappuccino, and delicious pizza. Looked at some ceramic art and took a nap in the grass. To our adorable B&B. Our room was the 'Romantic Suite'. It was gorgeous and many shades of pink and there were little treats dotted all around it. We then explored the castle and sat by the river. We found a quaint restaurant for dinner where we ate drank spritzes and ate donkey ragu, sardine & fennel macaroni, and gelato. Explored the area around the Roman theatre.

Had a quick cold shower, then coffee, and caught the train to Venice.
Locations: Verona, Venice, Ljubljana, Zagreb, Sibenik, Park Krka, Split Mostar, Dubrovnik

Description:
Early ride on the Eurostar. To Holybelly for a breakfast of great coffee, hash brown tangles, honey goat cheese, and chives on eggs. Napped. To Muji. Ate a chicken curry sandwich and hot dog. Through a shady street market to an 80's antique mall. Saw many great shops including one that specialized in old printing press letters. To Mary Celeste for a delicious spritz and an Autumn Blossom. To Candelaria for a variation on a martini and something smoky and sweet for Liz. To Little Red Door for a tiki drink and a Spots and Dots. To Mabel's for more great drinks. We walked 12 miles that day.

To Fondacion for coffee and cake. Then to a massive street antique market. Lots of mid-century stuff. We ate Andouillette and fries. To Institute de Bourse for nice coffee in very hot ceramic cups. Paris has a canal; it was empty. Ate a ham, egg, and cheese crepe and a Nutella crepe. To printing press letter shop #2. Walked by Moulin Rouge. To Dirty Dick for two Monkey Seeds, a Ward 69, and a Dark Shaman. They were playing Messer Chups, an excellent Russian Surf Rock band. Had a brief hang with Alvin. Ate Chinese food. To Le Syndicat for bare walls, hip hop, and great drinks, one of which included beet juice.

Took the Eurostar back.

Waited in the very cold for a bus into town. We walked by ducks and swans in the water. We were in the snow. Went in and immediately out of a curry place because it was $25-30 for a curry. Instead we opted for good pizza and a bland kebab across the street. Had a long walk in the snow to the bonfire on the river. It was deserted, but warm. Walked just a short distance to our hostel where we met two geologists. We hit if off right away and ran out to the bonfire on the river just in time to be surrounded by mountains of fireworks all around us. We drank a bottle of Veuve Clicquot in the snow. We didn't stay out long due to the cold. Back inside we talked about cattle hydration and tectonic plates. I snored all night apparently. Sorry.

Hot dogs from Bæjarins Beztu Pylsur ('The Towns Best Sausages'), a popular hot dog stand, for a late breakfast. Went to the big church. We missed mass, but were still able to hear the incredibly beautiful organ. Didn't see the aurora. Had some great Thai noodles and then a drink in the London Underground themed Kaffibarinn. Took nice pictures. Watched Smarter Brother.

Ate delicious bagels from Kaffitar. Saw maybe too many penises at the Phallological Museum. A dog jumped on me. Ate more hot dogs from Bæjarins; these were great hot dogs. Ate fish stew, fish kebab, and a potato kebab at Sea Baron. Went on a Northern Lights tour. We didn't see any with our eyeballs, but I took many long-exposure photos with some green shades in them. Ate two more hot dogs (5.5 total for me) and slept in a room that was way too cold. Back to London.

This town didn't fancy us. Went onto Saint-Louis. Much cuter. Nice pizza. Our Airbnb smelled like smoke, but Alicia was nice, had some fun music to share, and I didn't poop the bed (*see Freiburg trip) so it was a good night. We didn't even throw up our dinners!

Up. Returned the car — only stalled once, and went the fuck home.

I threw up on the bus to Stansted. I quickly realized I had either food poisoning (possibly from a batch of homemade sauerkraut we just tested) or a case of Norovirus. Made it to Basel. Felt like hell. Got our manual car, which I now know how to drive (*see Tahiti trip). Drove to Freiburg. Potato soup w/weiner and pumpkin lasagne in a nice restaurant. People stared at us for some reason. I was struck with an allergy attack and proceeded to sneeze violently throughout our entire meal. Met the lovely Marta and Niko (from Poland) at the Airbnb. Earlier I had mentioned I wasn't feeling well so Marta made us a batch of yummy and restorative lemon ginger water. Nap. Woke up with a wet butt. Threw those undies away (2/3 left). Out to the Christmas Market. Ate potato cakes and a nutella crepe. To bed. Up in the night...it happened again (1/3 undies left). I padded the last pair heavily with TP and went back to bed. Up again. Change padding and threw up my lunch and dinner. Liz apparently was also feeling ill (though without the incontinence, fortunately).

Morning (0 underwear left). Cold balls. Went shopping for new briefs, but all the shops were closed because Europe on a Sunday. Ate some soup and a nice brat. Edged up to the Black Forest and explored a cute town on a hill. Took pictures and found cats. Drove to Basel.

Entrées

Les Halles de Lyon: Langoustine, oursins, pince de crabe, thon, champagne, abricot.

Deux Rivières: Mokxa pour café, photographie, surréaliste à la Galerie le Réverbère, Alix, chat, hookah.

Les Culottes Longues: Foie gras avec quenelle, du boeuf, vin, bouteille lourd!

Snug: Justine, Tequila Sunrise, decibel counter, il faisait très froid, voiture électrique

Plats

Truffle: Foie gras ravioles, jambon et fromage pâtisserie

Croix Rousse: Belle vue sur la ville, photos mignons

Vieux Lyon: Café de la cathédrale, la pluie sur la place

Mozzato: Burrata fumée, gnocchi, voisin gentil, long island iced tea

Desserts

Vieux Lyon: Pizza café et brioche aux pralines

Miniature Musée: Mere etrangere, petits mondes

Traboules du Vieux Lyon: poussant chaque porte

Le Poêlon d'Or: Andouillette avec moutarde, quenelle en sauce écrevisse

Silka: du cafe

To a burger place. Came upon a very nice church. We stayed in a charming and cheap room.

To another lovely church. Ate a Pari-Brest, an abricot, and some cheesy bread. The river was picturesque, as was pretty much the entire town. We let ourselves get lost wandering the quaint streets. Found a nice cafe in a square where we drank coffee and ate foie gras. Took a boat ride and to a busier area where we saw tour groups on boats, bicycles, foot, and Seaguey. I took some nice photos of Liz on the bridge. She took some of me too. Had a beautiful panoramic view. Stopped by a sandwich shop for one baguette with ham & pickled veggies and another with salmon and cheese. They were both fantastic. We ate them in front of the futuristic Victorian train station and then went inside the station to, reluctantly, head home.

Many humans. Many drunk. Saw some posh suede lederhosen. Also saw lots of cheap lederhosen. Into the madness. It was essentially a massive carnival with lots of places to drink beer. Got a big beer. Met an exotic animal dentist. Prost. Remember to make eye contact. Currywurst. Wow Germans speak great English. Another beer! Lucky Strike. Wow, that's a lot of beer. Wow, that's strong beer. Mostly hung at the Augustiner tent. Another sausage. I was so drunk my jaw locked and I could hardly open it enough to eat a brat. I had to pee so bad I could hardly walk. Wow, we are really drunk. I think we ate fries later.

Terrible falafel. Terrible hangover. Back to the party. The beer hall smelled disgusting. People were chanting loudly and smacking their tankards on the tables in unison. A nice horn band was playing. Roasted fish. Aebleskiver on an edible foam plate. Went on a cute 'scary' ride. It had giant chattering teeth and was reminiscent of the ride in Amilee. We watched people tumble down the toboggan conveyor belt for at least half an hour. Ate more meat sticks. Then took a rideshare to Strasbourg.

The streets were narrow. There were loads of humans about. We ate a lamb brat and beef brat with soft buns. To an ivy covered church. Visited a craft fair along the river. Purchased a few ceramic poppies for Anne. Got stuck by a spiny shrub. Relaxed on the bank and practiced HDR photography. There were many refugees in the train station sitting and sleeping behind barricades. It was surprising to be so directly confronted with the issue of displaced people. Part of a building was missing and it was beautiful. Headed to Munich.

In no particular order: Drank coffee at Fuglen. Saw the Sky Tree. Tried tsukemen in Ramen Alley. Snacked on sweet crab treats. Crunched tempura. Mourned the karakasa. Savored Yasuda's sushi. Ate crispy katsukura. Sampled shabu shabu. Drunkenly walked two miles at 2AM to Tsukiji market for the tuna auction. Saw the seafood market. Bought a whetstone.

Rode electric bicycles. Bar 5 turned us away. Went inside some very loud arcades. Munched on mochi. Had egg custard cups in Ginza. Ate crepes in Harajuku. Saw the robots in Shinjuku. Watched the parade in Meiji Jingu. Fell in love with Gudetama. Felt slummy in Mikimoto. Joined the crowd in Senso-ji. Ate Ukrainian food and a snow cone with Noriko. Slurped soft cream. Bought some manga.

Tried Switch Coffee. Ate some Wagyu. Grilled chicken in Piss Alley. Napped during some Kabuki. Drank lots of wine. Appreciate the beauty of the conbini. Tried takoyaki. Drank whisky at Star Bar, where ryan ate Iberico fat. Had some cheaper drinks at L-Bar.

Day trip to San Marino. There were great views and the company was superlative. Carpaccio and homemade pasta for lunch. There were fake guns and imitation perfume for sale. Bethany bought a painting from a man painting on the street. Back to the villa where we ate leftovers for dinner.

Brigetta and Uwe made food all day. They served eggs and fruit for breakfast. We hung by the pool. To the store to buy cheese and more alcohol. We took family photos. The Nivens arrived. For dinner we had wine, turkey, tuna mayo, caprese salad, bruschetta, pesto pasta, strawberry cream cake, and two types of tiramisu. We took a few more photos and off we go. We slept at airport. Martino (a prior Couchsurfer in London) was our security agent.

Landed and went straight into work.
People: Richard, Anne, Catherine, and Phoebe Miller, Bethany, Anne and Peter Niven, Brigetta and Uwe, Peggy, Connor, and Peggy's sister
Locations: Rome, Perugia, Genoa, Milan, Arezzo, San Gimignano, Cinque Terra, Volterra, Siena, Florence, San Marino

Description: Liz and I only to Florence. Walked around. There were many tour groups out and it was quite hot. We ate gelato. We got hot and tired. Came back. Brigetta and Uwe arrived. Nice crowd. Great lasagna.
Locations: Rome, Perugia, Genoa, Milan, Arezzo, San Gimignano, Cinque Terra, Volterra, Siena, Florence, San Marino

Description: I nearly bought an alabaster chess set. We had a light lunch of bresaola with melon, rocket, and mozzarella. Shopped around the town a bit. Found a big red circle overlooking a valley on the road To Sienna. Visited an unreal cathedral. Peggy treated us to dinner back in Arezzo. There were too many appetizers and many of the girls kissed the waiter.
People: Richard, Anne, Catherine, and Phoebe Miller, Bethany, Anne and Peter Niven, Peggy, Connor, and Peggy's sister
Locations: Rome, Perugia, Genoa, Milan, Arezzo, San Gimignano, Cinque Terra, Volterra, Siena, Florence, San Marino

Description: Rode with Peggy and group. Barely made it to the ferry on time. Toured Monterosso. Ate a nice fish stew and mussels pasta. Walked around and had gelato. Took the boat back and stopped by Pisa. Had a weird encounter with a 'parking attendant', who was just some guy who 'helped us park our car' and then wanted money. Took silly pictures in front of the tower, as you do. Back to villa for a lovely chicken parmesan made by Anne.
Locations: Rome, Perugia, Genoa, Milan, Arezzo, San Gimignano, Cinque Terra, Volterra, Siena, Florence, San Marino

Description: Saw the tower. Ate a pizza. Sat in the square at the top of the stairs where we ate gelato. Liz's vintage green necklace broke and send beads racing down across the plaza. We scrambled to pick them up and recovered all but one. Saw some renaissance babies in a museum. Ate more gelato. Back to the villa for roast chicken dinner with baked potatoes made by Anne.
People: Richard, Anne, Catherine, and Phoebe Miller, Bethany, Peggy, Connor, and Peggy's sister
Locations: Rome, Perugia, Genoa, Milan, Arezzo, San Gimignano, Cinque Terra, Volterra, Siena, Florence, San Marino

Description:
To Genoa. There were men preaching in the streets. Walked by the shipyard. Then by a brothel alley. Ate some cheap pasta. Then to Milan.

Tried for Bar Luce, but there was a private event. To a cocktail bar called Nottingham Forest. It was bizarre and wonderful. Their menu was a binder with man A4 Word doc sheets in plastic. We ate pizza and olives. Liz: singing peach bellini. Me: Oysters (salt, leaves, campari). Both: Cloud (strawberry daiquiri). Drove back to Arezzo. We had a nice chat about early memories. Then it was our Anniversary! We slept in a gas station.
Locations: Rome, Perugia, Genoa, Milan, Arezzo, San Gimignano, Cinque Terra, Volterra, Siena, Florence, San Marino

Description: Over the course of a few days here we did many things. I gave Liz her birthday card. We met up with many lovely humans including: Richard, Anne, Catherine, and Phoebe Miller, Bethany, Anne and Peter Niven, Brigetta and Uwe, Peggy, Connor, and Peggy's sister whose name I cannot recall. We drank Cynar spritzes by the pool and champagne all over. Anne made many lovely meals including a fantastic chicken parmesan. The younger folks and I made pizzas which turned out pretty well one night. Brigetta made a lovely meal on her first night in. Peggy treated us to a nice dinner out at a nearby restaurant. We toured the winery and drank some delicious wines while getting to know the charming family who runs the place. I learned about, drank, and purchased some very nice Vin Santo.
People: Richard, Anne, Catherine, and Phoebe Miller, Bethany, Anne and Peter Niven, Brigetta and Uwe, Peggy, Connor, and Peggy's sister
Locations: Rome, Perugia, Genoa, Milan, Arezzo, San Gimignano, Cinque Terra, Volterra, Siena, Florence, San Marino

Description:
Ate a nice sandwich and mini cannoli in the terminal. Our B&B was cute and simple. Headed to the Coliseum where the line wasn't bad. There were many men selling selfie sticks out front. We walked a lot. To the Pantheon. For dinner we ate Gnocchi. Then to Jerry Thomas Speakeasy for cocktails. Walking back in the dark we saw many beautifully-lighted fountains that were quite majestic in the dark.

Breakfast was a cannoli and espresso at a nearby cafe. To the Roman Forum. It was already very hot so we didn't linger. Ate a heavenly salmon, dill, and ricotta croissant at Crystal Sugar. Crossed the bridge to Travestera. The river was reminiscent of vintage green glass. Drank a cafe freddo and picked up some beers for later. To the liquor store for Cynar and Vivese. Had an Aperol Spritz. Went for dinner at Da Enzo where we ate fried squash blossoms, a phenomenal cacio e pepe, and an umami packed rigatoni with a simple tomato sauce & guanciale. It was the best Italian food I'd ever had.

Picked up a rental car. Stopped by Crystal Sugar again for another salmon croissant. To Perugia. Walked up the hill and into the ancient city where we wandered and had Gelato. Drove to the Villa where we met the family and had sausages with wine.
Locations: Rome, Perugia, Genoa, Milan, Arezzo, San Gimignano, Cinque Terra, Volterra, Siena, Florence, San Marino

Description:
Got a car. To Shojo for Bok choy, kimchi fried rice, mushroom and pepper pasta ragu at Crouching Tiger. To Wusta. Cats! Lovely, cute, soft, smelly, scratchy, squeaky cats!

Hung a home with Kelly and Chris for a while. Checked out their vases. Kelly made nice cocktails.

Trader Joe's and Target. Chris made great waffles and maple syrup. Kenny came to hang. To Kelly's parents. Accents got thick quick. Liz suited up for bees. I didn't but got close anyway and took lots of pictures. One chased me for a minute, but that was it. I found the queen, which Kelly was worried she had killed previously. Met her uncle, Anne Frank, who was a nice guy. Cold brew, wrap, and chips. Bye pretty creatures. To Beverly. Late for the rehearsal dinner. NBD. Kind humans, great gouda, lovely lobster bisque. Nice hotel in downtown.

Nice napping in the morning. Hazelnut paste latte. Aids run. Damn fine grilled cheese and kitchen sink quesadilla. Iguana, rattlesnake, lamb brains, cow liver, flunken. Let's Dance, Mozart, Emotional Rescue. To the wedding. Flower in the asphalt. Broken glass. In My Life. The flower girls drop their petals. Lamb lollipops. Met Beth. Tent. Toast. Falafel and Salmon. Dancing. Sweating. Cake. Dancing. Raising chairs. Dancing. Traveling. Sleeping. Traveling.

Night bus into Paris.

Met Alvin at his place. Napped. Saw two people without toes and a groovy horn band. To Père-Lachaise to see the graves of Frédéric Chopin, Jim Morrison, Édith Piaf, Oscar Wylde, and Georges Méliès. There was a man peeing on the outer wall. Bought some very nice tea from Mariage Frères. Had drinks at Experimental Cocktail Club. Ate falafel on the street. The shop made animal heads from fruits and veggies. To Crazy Horse. Very nice bodies and entertaining theatre. Sometimes it was quite cheesy. Sputnik, Upside Down, Scanners, Girl on a Horse, Girls with Horse Tails, Tap Dancing Men. Lots of pubic hair and red leather. Alvin was dreaming about war when we returned.

To Coutume for strong cold brew and a mushroomy woody Ethiopian. To Pâtisserie des Rêves for Pari-Brest. Took a film photo booth strip in Palais de Tokyo. Outside Pompidou for pistachio ice cream and a crepe. 'Inside' Pompidou for lots of trite classic modern art, but also some quite good contemporary art. Saw nice view of Paris. Had expensive margaritas and great tacos at Candelaria. Alvin thought the chef dug me because he was being bickery with me. To Sherry Butt for great drinks (mine had a smoky tomato liqueur in it). Walked around the Louvre exterior and by the Seine. A horn band was playing Thrift Shop. Alvin taught us about Paris Syndrome, which is when tourists are often let down by Paris upon visiting due to unrealistic expectations. Watched Blue Jasmine.

Had pastries and coffee from Telescope then went to the airport.

We leave London on the night bus and get in late to the hotel.

A greasy bacon butty and then the bus, which drops us off at a train station about a mile from Haworth. There was a beautiful steam locomotive sitting on the tracks. I'm not sure if it even runs, but we ride in a vintage double-decker up the hill. Though it's May, but open air is still quite chilly. We are in Haworth, which truly feels like stepping back in time. People are dressed in impeccable 40's panoply. The shops mostly sell Britain-themed clothing or memorabilia. There are also many stalls selling the same and also food. There is a pristine Spitfire on display. We buy milk powder for the bath. Next we stop in a pub for bitter ale and chips. Afterward we visit a small Alan Turing museum where we see an Enigma, a German enciphering machine, and the Bombe, a deciphering proto-computer he invented. Then we have a sausage with cream tea. Later, we watched couples dance to a live swing band in the tent. As evening sets in we head to Bradford. We don't feel comfortable here and we can't find condoms. We eat chicken at Nando's. There's a fight outside. A man in the lift reminds us of Dracula.

A man at the bus stop Just. Keeps. Spitting. We eat bread and salami. And then sat in the grass for a cream tea. We take the steam train north. I chat with a nice older Irish man. Liz sits next to a young boy who she says smells like sugar. His hands are sticky and he repeatedly touches her skirt. I get a cask cream ale at the station before we return to London.

We pick up cheese, meat, and beer from the store before driving to Apeldoorn. We arrive at the hotel, shower, touch, and nap. We are feeling uninspired by dinner options so we snack on bitterballen and kasstangles in the hotel bar then proceed to drink beer in the room.

We drive down through the green areas on the map. This is Amsterdam's largest forest. It is pretty and very manicured.
Locations: Amsterdam, Alkmaar, Haarlem, Den Hague, Apeldoorn

Description: I almost back into a server (restaurant, not beep boop). He kindly yelled at me before I hit him. Our main stop here is the M.C. Escher Museum, where we spend hours learning just how much of a master and genius Escher was. We both are in awe at the beauty and ingenuity of his vast body of work. Next we head to Keukenhof, a massive flower garden with over 7 million flowers; nearly all of them tulips. We spend hours taking in seemingly endless varieties of tulips. I take A LOT of pictures. We drive back to Amsterdam and try for our favorite fondue place, but they close up just as we arrive. We get cheap falafel instead. To Tales & Spirits again where we drink a Zombie, a Bathtub, and more. We wander the red lights and arrive at Hiding in Plain Sight where we take in a rum punch and a citron brûlée flip. We sleep in the car again.
Locations: Amsterdam, Alkmaar, Haarlem, Den Hague, Apeldoorn

Description:
We hoped to catch the cheese market, but it is closing up just as we arrive. We stroll the town, and buy a vase for Catherine. Next we head to Haarlem for groceries and chocolate milk before returning to Amsterdam. We park for the evening and take a cab to Tales & Spirits. Our cab driver is clearly taking us the long way. I call him out and he complains for a while before offering a discount. The bar is small, lively, and charming. They serve one drink in a small bathtub. We order a Bird is the Word and Smoke and Mirrors; both are incredible. We sleep in the car on the side of the road near the library.

Up and to Den Hague.
Locations: Amsterdam, Alkmaar, Haarlem, Den Hague, Apeldoorn

Description: We have some difficulty figuring out the buses into the city. We get a car from a very hip car rental agency. Liz drives, but becomes quickly frustrated driving around Amsterdam. We get lunch from Signel 404 and eat on the canal bank just across the street. One sandwich is warm goat cheese with pine nuts, thyme, and honey. The other is 'Old Cheese', walnuts, sun-dried tomatoes, and honey mustard. We hit the road towards Alkmaar. I drive for the rest of the trip.
Locations: Amsterdam, Alkmaar, Haarlem, Den Hague, Apeldoorn

Description: We take an early train from London. Just outside the station we tour a mock court house populated by disturbing mannequins. We walk a lot.
